Question_1.Context: Based on the impact of welding factors on tensile properties, microhardness, and surface roughness of friction stir welded AA6061-T651,
Question_1.Question: What was the maximum value of ultimate tensile strength (UTS) achieved for the friction stir welded joints?
Question_1.Source: Increase in speed from 710 to 1400 rpm (at constant translation speed of 20 mm/min) linearly increases UTS from 0.37 to 0.44 kN/mm2.

Question_2.Context: Considering the microhardness profile of the friction stir welded joints,
Question_2.Question: Where was the maximum hardness of HV 120 achieved?
Question_2.Source: The maximum hardness of HV 120 was achieved for the stir zone (SZ).

Question_3.Context: Regarding the impact of rotational speed on surface roughness of the friction stir welded specimens,
Question_3.Question: At which rotational speed was the minimum average surface roughness observed?
Question_3.Source: Minimum average value of surface roughness of 6.71 μm was witnessed in specimen no. 8, i.e., at a rotational speed of 1400 rpm.

Question_4.Context: Considering the tensile test results of the base alloy and as-welded specimens,
Question_4.Question: What was the yield load for specimen no. 8 welded at a rotational speed of 1400 rpm and a welding speed of 20 mm/min?
Question_4.Source: Yield load for specimen no. 8 was 11.80.

Question_5.Context: Based on the microstructural analysis of the friction stir welded joint,
Question_5.Question: What was observed in the stirred zone (SZ) microstructure?
Question_5.B: Coarse grains oriented along the rolling direction
Question_5.C: Equiaxed grains somewhat oriented in the rolling direction
Question_5.Source: The SZ consists of noticeable onion ring structures.

Question_6.Context: Regarding the surface roughness testing results of the aluminum alloy AA6061-T651,
Question_6.Question: What was the effect of decreasing rotational speed on the surface roughness of the friction stir welded specimens?
Question_6.Source: As rotational speed decreases, roughness of the surface increases.

Question_7.Context: Considering the microhardness values of the friction stir welded samples,
Question_7.Question: What was the microhardness value at the boundary between the heat-affected zone (HAZ) and the thermomechanically affected zone (TMAZ) on the advancing side?
Question_7.Source: Boundary between HAZ and TMAZ on advancing side showed hardness value of HV 81.

Question_8.Context: Based on the tensile test results of the base alloy and as-welded specimens,
Question_8.Question: Which specimen had the maximum ultimate load?
Question_8.Source: Ultimate load for specimen no. 8 was the highest.

Question_9.Context: Regarding the microstructural aspects of the friction stir welded joints,
Question_9.Question: What is the primary reason for the increase in hardness in the stir zone (SZ)?
Question_9.Source: Fine recrystallized zone at weld nugget is because of substantial plastic deformation, followed by dynamic recrystallization.

Question_10.Context: Considering the conclusions drawn from the research work,
Question_10.Question: What was the maximum value of yield strength achieved for the friction stir welded joints?
Question_10.Source: Maximum value of UTS and yield strength are found at rotational speed of 1400 rpm and welding speed of 20 mm/min.
